{{ubl | [[Battle of Pelusium (525 BC)|Battle of Pelusium]] (525 BC) | [[Battle of Carchemish]] (605 BC) | [[Battle of Hamath]] (605 BC) | [[Battle of Megiddo (609 BC)|Battle of Megiddo]] (609 BC) | [[Fall of Ashdod]] (635 BC) | [[Battle of Qarqar]] (853 BC) | [[Battle of Bitter Lakes]] (925 BC) | [[Battle of Bitter Lakes]] (925 BC) | [[Battle of Kadesh]] (1274 BC) | [[Ramesses III#Tenure of constant war|Egyptian-Sea People wars]] (1,175 BC) | [[Battle of the Delta]] (1175 BC) | [[Battle of Djahy]] (1,178 BC) | [[Battle of Al Mansurah]] (8–11 February 1250) | [[French campaign in Egypt and Syria]] (1798–1801) | [[Mahdist War]] (1881–1899) | [[Greek War of Independence]] (1821–1832) | [[Egyptian–Ottoman War (1831–1833)|First Egyptian-Ottoman War]] (1831–1833) | [[Egyptian–Ottoman War (1839–1841)|Second Egyptian-Ottoman War]](1839–1841) | [[Ethiopian–Egyptian War]] (1875–1876) | [['Urabi Revolt]] (1879–1882) | [[Anglo-Egyptian War]] (1882) | [[World War I]] (1914–1918) | [[World War II]] (1939–1945) | [[1948 Arab–Israeli War]] (1948–1949) | [[Suez Crisis]] (1956) | [[North Yemen Civil War]] (1962–1970) | [[Six-Day War]] ( 5–10 June 1967) | [[Nigerian Civil War]] (1967–1970) | [[War of Attrition]] (1967–1970) | [[Yom Kippur War]] (1973–1974) | [[1977 Egyptian bread riots|Egyptian bread riots]] (18–19 January 1977) | [[Libyan–Egyptian War]] ( 21–24 July 1977) | [[Gulf War]] (1990–1991) | [[Egyptian Crisis (2011–present)|Egyptian Crisis]] (2011–14) | [[Sinai insurgency]] (2011 – present) | [[Second Libyan Civil War]] (2014 – present) |[[Military intervention against ISIL]] (16 February 2015 – present) | [[2015 Egyptian military intervention in Libya|Intervention in Libya]] (16 February 2015 – present) | [[Saudi-led intervention in Yemen (2015–present)|Intervention in Yemen]] (25 March 2015 – present) | [[List of conflicts in Egypt|Other]] }}

article.paragraph: TheEgyptian Armed Forces(EAAF) (lang-arالقوات المسلحة المصرية;IPA-arel qouwat el mosalaha el masriya) are themilitary forcesof Egypt and are the largest in Africa and the Middle East, and also one of the largest in the world. They consist of theEgyptian ArmyArmy,Egyptian NavyNavy,Egyptian Air ForceAir ForceandEgyptian Air Defense CommandAir Defense Command.

The supreme commander of the armed forces is thePresident of EgyptPresident of the Republicas provided for in theHistory of the Egyptian ConstitutionEgyptian constitution. TheSupreme Council of the Armed Forcesconsists of 20 to 25 members, headed by theList of Ministers of Defence of EgyptCommander-in-Chief and Defence Ministerand his deputy, theList of Chiefs of the General Staff of EgyptChief of Staffof the Armed Forces. Members of the council are formed of the leaders of the main military branches (Egyptian Air ForceAirEgyptian NavyNavyEgyptian Air Defense ForcesAir DefenseBorder guard#EgyptBorder Guard) and the leaders of the two armies (Second Army (Egypt)Second ArmyAndThird Army (Egypt)Third Army) in addition to the leaders of the military regions (Western Military Region (Egypt)Western Military ZoneNorthern Military Region (Egypt)Northern Military ZoneSouthern region military (Egypt)Southern Military ZoneCentral military region (Egypt)Central Military Zone) along with the heads of the upper bodies (Chief of Operations Reinforcement Logistics Engineering Training Finance Military Justice Management and Administration), administrative managers (Military Intelligence and Director of Morale Affairs) and the Assistant Defense Secretary for Constitutional and Legal Affairs and Secretary General of the Department of Defense (Secretary of the Council).

The Egyptian army is one of the oldest armies in history, the first of its wars began to unite Egypt at the hands ofPharaohKingMenesin 3200 BC,cite webhttp://www.au.af.mil/au/awc/awcgate/gabrmetz/gabr0005.htmThe Armies of the Pharaohs, 3200–1300 BC[[Air University (United States Air Force)|The Air University]]2015-05-03and have fought major wars and battles over the centuries, from thePharaonicera and throughPtolemaic KingdomPtolemaicandEgypt (Roman province)Romania,Egypt in the Middle AgesIslamicand evenHistory of modern Egyptmodern era. The Egyptian army have foughtList of conflicts in Egyptbattles and wars in many parts of the world, mostly defensive, with the most notable being: theHyksosHyksos War,Battle of Ain Jalut,Battle of Al Mansurah,Battle of Nezib,Battle of Megiddo (15th century BC)Battle of Megiddo,Battle of Carchemish,Battle of Hattin,OttomanWahhabi WarEgyptianSaudi War,Anglo-Egyptian War,Battle of Tel el-Kebir,Greek War of Independence,EgyptianOttoman War (183133)EgyptianOttoman War,Middle Eastern theatre of World War IWorld War I,Military history of Egypt during World War IIWorld War II,1948 Arab-Israeli War,Egyptian Revolution of 1952,Suez CrisisTripartite Aggression,North Yemen Civil War,Six Day War,Nigerian Civil War,War of Attrition,Yom Kippur WarOctober War,Shaba I,LibyanEgyptian War,Gulf War,Egyptian Crisis (2011present)Egyptian Crisis, and theSinai insurgency.

Equipment of the modern Egyptian ArmyMilitary equipmentvaries in the Egyptian army between eastern and western armament, coming from several countries through mutual military cooperation, including the United States, Russia, France, Italy, Ukraine, China, as well as locally from theArab Organization for IndustrializationAOIandMinistry of Military Production (Egypt)MMP.

The power of the Egyptian Armed Forces since theArab Springhas caused it to be called a "state within a state".Cite newshttp://www.haaretz.com/news/middle-east/1.560795Egypt's new constitution strengthens army's 'state within a state' statusHaaretz28 November 20132 December 2014ReutersCite newshttp://www.huffingtonpost.com/barry-lando/egypt-coup_b_3545469.htmlEgypt's Military State Within a StateBarry Lando''The Huffington Post''That turbulence was threatening not just the survival of Egypt, but, more to the point, it was menacing the vast state within a state that Egypt's military presides over.4 July 20132 December 2014
article.heading: Overview
article.paragraph: The Headquarters of the Egyptian Armed Forces are in Koubri el-Quba, Cairo. TheList of Ministers of Defence of EgyptCommander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces, the senior uniformed officer, is currentlyEgyptian Army ranksColonel GeneralSedki Sobhiand theList of Chiefs of the General Staff of EgyptChief of Staffis currentlyEgyptian Army ranksLieutenant GeneralMahmoud Hegazy. TheMinistry of Defence (Egypt)Ministry of Defenseis responsible for managing the affairs of the Egyptian Armed Forces and maintaining its facilities.

The Armed Forces' inventory includes equipment from different countries around the world. Equipment from the formerSoviet Unionis being progressively replaced by more modern US, French, and British equipment, a significant portion of which is built under license in Egypt, such as theM1 Abramstank.Egypt remains a strong military and strategic partner and is a participant in NATO'sMediterranean Dialogueforum. The Egyptian military is one of the strongest in the region,cite webhttp://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/180382/Egypt#tabEgypt[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]2009-03-31and gives Egypt regional military supremacy rivaled only by Israel,cite webhttp://www.acpr.org.il/NATIV/2000-6/2000-6-shawnpinexs.htmThe Egyptian Threat and the Prospects for War in the Middle EastNovember 2006NATIV2009-03-31besides being one of the strongest in Africa.cite bookhttp://books.google.com/?idGlobal Diversity: Winning Customers and Engaging Employees Within World Markets2006Intercultural Press2009-03-319781904838098Egypt is one of the few countries in the Middle East, and the only Arab state, with areconnaissance satelliteand has launched another one in 2014.cite webhttp://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cidEgypt to launch first spy satellite[[The Jerusalem Post]]2009-03-31

However the Egyptian armed forces were not in such a good state in the mid 1950s. Just before theSuez Crisis, political allegiance rather than military competence was the main criterion for promotion.Varble, Derek (2003) p. 19.The Egyptian commander, Field MarshalAbdel Hakim Amer, was a purely political appointee who owed his position to his close friendship with Nasser. A heavy drinker, he would prove himself grossly incompetent as a general during the Crisis.In 1956, the armed forces was well equipped with weapons from the Soviet Union such asT-34andIS tank family#IS-3IS-3tanks,MiG-15fighters,Ilyushin Il-28bombers,SU-100self-propelled guns and assault rifles.Rigid lines between officers and men in the Egyptian Army led to a mutual "mistrust and contempt" between officers and the men who served under them.Varble, Derek (2003) p. 20.Egyptian troops were excellent in defensive operations, but had little capacity for offensive operations, owing to the lack of "rapport and effective small-unit leadership".

In January 2011, a delegation led by the chief of staff of Egypt's armed forces, Lt. Gen.Sami Hafez Enan, was in Washington, D.C., although the visit was truncated due to theEgyptian Revolution of 2011protests. The sessions, an annual country-to-country military coordination, were being led for the U.S. by Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security AffairsAlexander Vershbow. A meeting with Adm.Mike Mullen, chairman of the U.S.Joint Chiefs of Staff, and other talks had been planned to extend to 2 February. However, in light of events in Egypt, the delegation left Washington to return home.Elisabeth BumillerBumiller, Elisabeth(28 January 2011)."Egyptian Military Chiefs Cut Pentagon Visit Short".The New York Times. Retrieved 28 January 2011.Before their Friday night departure, Vershbow urged the two dozen Egyptian military representatives "to exercise 'restraint'".Bumiller, Elisabeth; Mark Landler contributed reporting,"Calling for Restraint, Pentagon Faces Test of Influence With Ally".The New York Times. 29 January 2011 (30 January 2011, p. A1, New York edition). Retrieved 30 January 2011.

TheSupreme Council of the Armed Forceswas convened during the course of theEgyptian Revolution of 2011, and assumed power when Mubarak resigned on 11 February 2011.cite newshttp://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/feb/11/crowds-rejoice-egypts-mubarak-steps-down/Murdock, HeatherCrowds rejoice as Egypt's Mubarak steps down, hands power to military[[The Washington Times]]11 February 201111 February 2011

On Sunday 12 August 2012, newly elected PresidentMohamed Morsiannounced a series of military appointments.Hussein Tantawi, the Minister of Defence and Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces was retired.http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/50239/Egypt/Politics-/Morsi-retires-Egypts-top-army-leaders;-amends--Con.aspxMorsi also retiredSami Anan, the Army's Chief of Staff. Morsi awarded both men state medals and appointed them as advisors to the president. Thirdly, the president appointed the head of military intelligence,Abdul Fatah al-Sisi, as Minister of Defence to replace Tantawi.Sedki Sobhi, the commander of the Third Army, was appointed as Chief of Staff of the Armed Forces. Morsi also retired the Commander of the Navy, Mohab Memish, and appointed him as head of the Suez Canal Authority.

On 3 July 2013 in response to millions of Egyptians demands demonstrating in streets all over Egypt since 30 June 2013,cite webMohamed Morsi ousted in Egypt's second revolution in two yearshttp://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/03/mohamed-morsi-egypt-second-revolutionThe Guardian3 July 20133 July 2013cite webMohamed Morsi ousted in Egypt's second revolution in two yearshttp://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2013/06/seeking-new-leadership-millions-of-egyptians-take-to-the-streets/277419/The Atlantic30 June 201330 June 2013cite webAnti-Mursi 'Rebel' campaign receives more than 22 million signatureshttp://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2013/06/29/-Rebel-campaign-receives-more-than-22-million-signatures-in-anti-Mursi-petition.htmlAl Arabiya29 June 201329 June 2013cite webMillions flood Egypt's streets to demand Mursi quithttp://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/30/us-egypt-protests-idUSBRE95Q0NO20130630Reuters30 June 201330 June 2013cite webEgypt protests: President Morsi removed by army, reportedly put under house arresthttp://www.thestar.com/news/world/2013/07/03/egypt_protests_mohammed_morsi_banned_from_travel_military_coup_underway_advisor_says.htmlThe Associated Press and Reuters3 July 2013the head of the Egyptian Armed Forces, then-Colonel GeneralAbdel Fattah el-Sisi,2013 Egyptian coup d'tatannounced the removalof President Mohamed Morsi from power, the suspension of theEgyptian Constitution of 2012constitution, and new presidential and House of Representatives elections. The severe crackdown on theMuslim Brotherhood in EgyptMuslim Brotherhoodand pro-Morsi supporters commenced. Notable incidents such as the2013 Republican Guard headquarters clashesand theAugust 2013 Rabaa massacreclaimed the lives of hundreds to thousands of demonstrators by military and police forces.cite newsKirkpatrickDavidAn Egypt Arrest, and a Brotherhood on the Runhttp://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/21/world/middleeast/egypt.html?pagewanted25 September 2013New York Times20 August 2013Mayy El Sheikh

The US provides annual military assistance to the Egyptian Armed Forces. In 2009, the U.S. providedReal versus nominal value (economics)nominal$1.3 billion to the Egyptian military ($formatnum:billion inCURRENTISOYEAR).cite webhttp://www.wikileaks.ch/cable/2009/05/09CAIRO874.htmlScenesetter: President Mubarak's visit to Washington19 May 2009US Department of Statecite webhttp://www.couriermail.com.au/ipad/nation-locked-in-a-deadly-stalemate/story-fn6ck51p-1225997761161Nation locked in a deadly stalemateThe Courier-MailDavid Costello1 February 20112011-02-11Much of this is in equipment such as tanks and jet fighters that are surplus to Egyptian needs and kept in storage."Egypt May Not Need Fighter Jets, But The U.S. Keeps Sending Them Anyway."

According to Article 200 of theEgyptian Constitution of 2014Egyptian Constitution, the Armed Forces belong to the People, and their duty is to protect the country, and preserve its security and the integrity of its territories.
article.heading: Politics
article.paragraph: multiple imageleft 185 185 vertical '''Top:''' [[Tahrir Square]] protestsers on 9 February; '''Bottom:''' An Egyptian soldier atop a tank in Tahrir Square. Tahrir Square - February 9, 2011.png Soldier in Tahrir.jpg The Armed Forces enjoy considerable power, prestige and independence within the Egyptian state.cite newsCambanisThanassisSuccession Gives Army a Stiff Test in Egypthttp://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/12/world/middleeast/12egypt.html?_r11 September 2010[[New York Times]]11 September 2010

During almost the entirehistory of the Republic of Egypt, active or retired military officers have been head of the Egyptian state. The first democratically-elected president who served for one year was2013 Egyptian coup d'tatremoved by a military coupafter theJune 2013 Egyptian proteststhroughout Egypt. Even theEgyptian Constitution of 2012constitutiondrafted and passed under Morsi included protections for the military from legal and parliamentary oversight,cite newsKIRKPATRICKDAVID D.Egypt Opposition Gears Up After Constitution Passeshttp://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/24/world/middleeast/as-egypt-constitution-passes-new-fights-lie-ahead.html26 September 2013New York Times23 December 2012MAYY EL SHEIKHthe constitution's principal defects were not about religion. The biggest problem, he said, is that it protects the Egyptian military from legal and parliamentary oversight, engraving its autonomy in the constitution. Leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood had said privately for months that they were willing to provide the military such constitutional protections in order to ease the transition of power from the generals who assumed control from Mr. Mubarak.and deferred to "objections from the country's military leadership" by removing a "clear prohibition on trials of civilians beforeHuman rights in Egypt under the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces#Military trialsmilitary courts" some drafters had tried to include.cite webEgypt: New Constitution Mixed on Support of Rightshttp://www.hrw.org/news/2012/11/29/egypt-new-constitution-mixed-support-rightsNovember 30, 2012Human Rights Watch26 September 2013But the latest draft, unlike the earlier version, defers to objections from the country's military leadership and removes the clear prohibition on trials of civilians before military courts.

Starting with theEgyptian Revolution of 1952, which created the Republic of Egypt, and was organized by theFree Officers Movement (Egypt)Free Officers Movement, presidents of EgyptGamal Abdel Nasser,Anwar Sadat,Hosni Mubarakwere ex-military officers for almost 60 years. This was interrupted with theEgyptian Revolution of 20112011 revolution, when PresidentMubarakwas forced to step down by the military in response to the revolution, and theSupreme Council of the Armed Forcesruled until it held aEgyptian presidential election, 2012presidential electionwhich resulted inMohamed Morsitaking office. On 3 July 2013, responding to millions in the streets, the head of the Armed Forces then-Egyptian Army ranksGeneralAbdel Fattah el-Sisiannounced the2013 Egyptian coup d'tatremovalofMorsiand installation of the interim civilian president the Chief Justice ofSupreme Constitutional Court of EgyptSupreme Constitutional CourtAdly Mansour. On 4 July 2013, 68-year-old Mansour was sworn in as acting president. On 26 March 2014 el-Sisi resigned from the military, announcing he would stand as a candidate in theEgyptian presidential election, 20142014 presidential election.cite webhttp://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/97612/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-ElSisi-bids-military-farewell,-says-he-will.aspxEgypt's El-Sisi bids military farewell, says he will run for presidencyAhram Online26 March 201427 March 2014He won the 2628 May 2014 election in a landslide.cite newsFormer army chief scores landslide victory in Egypt presidential pollshttp://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/may/29/abdel-fatah-al-sisi-sweeps-victory-egyptian-election29 May 2014''The Guardian''Sisi was sworn into office asPresident of Egypton 8 June 2014.
article.heading: Business
article.paragraph: The military has its own hospitals, factories, clubs, and gas stations staffed by its officers, soldiers, and civilians. The organization is influential in business circles, engaging in road and housing construction, consumer goods, resort management,and owning extensive tracts of real estate. Much military information is not made publicly available, including budget information, the names of the general officers and the military's size (which is considered a state secret).According to journalistJoshua Hammer, "as much as 40% of theEconomy of EgyptEgyptian economy" is controlled by the Egyptian military.Egypt: Who Calls the Shots?(relevance?) Joshua Hammer| nybooks.com| 18 August 2011| (free online article not complete, does not include quoted portion).the number which is described as a "myth" by some economists and journalists and contribution considered by some as "necessary" for the Egyptian economy and the needs of the Armed Forces to maintains its strength.Army Economy between dramatize and the dismantling of the state12 April 2012| (Arabic Article).
article.heading: Structure
article.paragraph: Image: .pngthumb220pxlegend#78B3FF[[military Western Region (Egypt)|Military Western Region]]legendRed[[military northern region (Egypt)|Military Northern Region]]legend#FF0099[[southern region military (Egypt)|Southern Region Military]] {{legend|#FEC82C|[[central military region (Egypt)|Central Military Region]]}} {{legend|Black|[[Unified Command of the area east of the canal (Egypt)|East Military Canal Zone]]}} {{legend|Blue|[[Second Army (Egypt)|Second Field Army]]}} {{legend|Cyan|[[Third Army (Egypt)|Third Field Army]]}}Egyptian Armed Forces, consists of several main branches, departments and authorities. Main branches are theEgyptian ArmyArmy, theEgyptian Air ForceAir Forces, theEgyptian Air Defense CommandAir Defense, and theEgyptian NavyNavy.

TheEgyptian Armyis administratively divided into 4 tactical commands (Northern, Western, Central, Southern command), each command is under control of aEgyptian Army ranksMajor Generalin addition to two armies (2nd, 3rd army) and different corps and divisions (Armor, Mechanized, Artillery, Airmobile, Airborne, Infantry, frontier, military police, intelligence,Republican Guard (Egypt)Republican guards, Special Forces). TheEgyptian Air Force(EAF) are the second biggest branch under control of the armed forces. The EAF has over 1,309 combat aircraft, 321 armed helicopters and controls about 17 air base. TheEgyptian Navyis the largest branch under the armed forces' control, it is the largest navy in the Middle East and Africa, and is the seventh largest in the world measured by the number of vessels. TheEgyptian Air Defense Forcesis the latest established branch in the Armed Forces consists of 30,000 officers & soldiers plus 40,000 conscripts.

Departments of the Egyptian Armed Forces include the Departments of Armament Affairs, Officers' Affairs, Management and Administration and the Department of Morale Affairs (DMA) which is responsible for managing the Egyptian Armed Forces' public image, boosting goodwill towards troops, writing the speeches of the Armed forces' public statements, contacting the media and organizing the Egyptian Armed Forces' conferences and symposiums. Moreover, The Medical management of the armed forces is responsible for managing the medical affairs of the armed forces as well as controlling the hospitals run by the Armed Forces which serves both civilians and military personnel estimated at 19 hospitals inCairo, 8 inAlexandria, 3 inMatrouh GovernorateMatrouh, 2 in each ofIsmailiaandGharbia GovernorateGharbia, one in each ofPort Said,Al Sharqia GovernorateAl Sharqia,Dakahlia GovernorateDakahlia,Beni Suef GovernorateBeni Suef,Minya GovernorateMinya,Sohag,Qena GovernorateQena,Aswan,Kafr el-Sheikh GovernorateKafr el-Sheikh, andNorth Sinai GovernorateNorth Sinai.cite newsEgyptian Armed Forces Hospitalshttp://www.mod.gov.eg/Mod/Mod_Hosp.aspx

Authorities of the armed forces include the Engineering Authority (EAAF), it's the sector beneath the Armed Forces responsible for the Engineering work, its missions variety between War and peace time, In War time the authority is responsible for the engineering aid to the Forces, one of the Authority major operations wasOperation Badr (1973)Operation Badr. In Peace time the authority is responsible in helping build Egypt's infrastructure and the national projects including Cities, stadiums, clubs. In addition to The Financial Authority (FA) responsible for the financial matters in the armed forces and the Research Authority.
The armed forces also hold control of military judiciary and military intelligence directorate.
article.heading: Structure of the field armies

link.part: Structure of theFirst Field Army(click to enlarge)
Structure of theSecond Army (Egypt)Second Field Army(click to enlarge)
Structure of theThird Army (Egypt)Third Field Army(click to enlarge)

article.heading: Personnel
article.paragraph: In 2011, The Egyptian armed forces is reported to have more than 468,500 active personnel, in addition to 800,000 personnel available in reserve and over 400,000 paramilitary personnel making itList of countries by number of military and paramilitary personnelone of the largest armies in the world. The recruitment in Egypt is mandatory for all men who reached the military service age. Only the medical committee formed by the Armed forces can exempt those who they decide as unsuitable for the military service. Men who have no brothers are also exempted.factOctober 2015

table.style: border:0px solid #8888aa; background-color:#FFFFFF; padding:5px; font-size:100%; margin: 0px 0px 0px 0px;

template.arg: [[File:Flag of the Army of Egypt.svg|25px]] [[Egyptian Army]]
[[File:Egypt Air Defense Flag.png|25px]] [[Egyptian Air Defense Forces]]

article.heading: Main Military Branches
Egyptian Army
article.paragraph: File:M1-A1 Abrams 1.jpgthumbM1 Abrams; the main tank of theEgyptian Army. This particular image shows a U.S. Marine Corps tankmainEgyptian ArmyThe inventory of the Egyptian armed forces includes equipment from the United States, France, the United Kingdom, theSoviet Union, and the People's Republic of China. Equipment from the Soviet Union is being progressively replaced by more modern U.S., French, and British equipment, a significant portion of which is built under license in Egypt, such as theM1 AbramsM1A2 Abramstankwhich makes Egypt the owner of the second largest number of latest generation main battle tanks in the region and the first in the case of the older generations.Conscripts for the army and other service branches without a university or secondary school degree serve three years as enlisted soldiers. Conscripts with a General Secondary School Degree serve two years as enlisted personnel. Conscripts with a university degree serve one year as enlisted personnel or three years as a reserve officer. Officers for the army are trained at theEgyptian Military Academyone of the oldest academies in the world.
article.heading: Egyptian Air Force
article.paragraph: File:Egyptian air force F-16 refueling.jpgthumbleftEgyptian F-16 Air RefuelingMainEgyptian Air ForceTheEgyptian Air ForceorEAFis the aviation branch of the Egyptian Armed Forces. Currently, the backbone of the EAF is theF-16. The EAF (planes and pilot training) is considered to be the strongest in Africa and one of the strongest in the Middle East. TheMirage 2000is the other modern interceptor used by the EAF. The Egyptian Air Force has 228 F-16s (plus 12 awaiting delivery) making it the 4th largest operator of the F-16 in the World. It has about 1,100 combat aircraftAircraft Strength by Countryand 245 armed helicopters.Helicopter Strength by Countryhaving at least 35 Apache's AH-64D as it also continues to fly extensively upgradedMiG-21s,F-7 Skybolts,F-4 Phantoms,Dassault Mirage Vs, and theC-130 Herculesamong other planes. The Air Force is undergoing massive modernization.Mikoyanin late 2014 confirmed that Egypt signed a deal to acquire 24MiG-29Mfighter jets, and is in negotiations to acquire 24 MiG-35 fighter jetsand it was reported that Egypt is in negotiations with French Dassault for an initial order of 24 Rafale fighter jets
article.heading: Egyptian Air Defense
article.paragraph: File:9A83ME TEL - Antey-2500 SAM 02.jpgthumbS-300VMEntered service in November 2014MainEgyptian Air Defense ForcesTheEgyptian Air Defense CommandorEADC(Quwwat El Diffaa El Gawwi in Arabic) is Egypt's military command responsible for air defense. One of the most powerful air defenses in the world. Egypt patterned its Air Defense Force (ADF) after the Soviet Anti-Air Defenses, which integrated all its air defense capabilities antiaircraft guns, rocket and missile units, interceptor planes, and radar and warning installations..
Its commander isEgyptian Army ranksLt. Gen.Abdul Meniem Al-Toras.
article.heading: Egyptian Navy
article.paragraph: Image:Fremm Tahya Misr.jpgthumb220pxleftFremm Tahya Misr leaving DCNS shipyard for her first sea trials with the Egyptian Navy crew on board.mainEgyptian NavyAlthough theEgyptian Navyis the smallest branch of the military, it is large by Middle Eastern standards. The Egyptian Navy is known to be the strongest in the African continent, and the largest in the Middle East in spite of the rapid growth of other countries' navies within the region.

Some fleet units are stationed in theRed Sea, but the bulk of the force remains in the Mediterranean. Navy headquarters and the main operational and training base are located at Ras el Tin near Alexandria.The current commander isVice admiralOsama El-Gendi.

The Navy also controls theEgyptian Coast Guard. The Coast Guard is responsible for the onshore protection of public installations near the coast and the patrol of coastal waters to prevent smuggling. It has an inventory consisting of about thirty five large patrol craft (each between twenty and thirty meters in length) and twenty smaller Bertram-class coastal patrol craft built in the United States.

paragraph.italics: Seelist of naval ships of Egyptfor a list of vessels in service.

article.heading: Egyptian Rapid deployment forces
article.paragraph: mainEgyptian Rapid deployment forcesEgyptian Rapid deployment forces (RDF) is one of the branches of the Egyptian Armed Forces. It was formed in March 2014 by the former defense minister field marshal Abdel Fattah al-Sisi. It is mainly airborne troops with a special formation, and it is characterized by the ability to perform operations inside and outside the Egyptian mainland. It comprises the most efficient elements of the mechanized Infantry, armored corps, air defense, artillery and anti-tank teams.
article.heading: Special Forces
article.paragraph:
multiple image219 260 horizontal '''Left:''' Member of [[Sa'ka Forces|Egyptian Thunderbolt Forces]] perform close range combat during a medal parade in Bukavu.
'''Right: '''Members of the [[Unit 777]] fire weapons during a combat marksmanship exercise at an indoor firing range. SRSG first visit to Bukavu (10225578553).jpg Unit 777.jpg Special forces in the Egyptian Armed forces are units under control of different branches. Most of the officers take the specialSa'ka ForcesSa'ka Course. In addition to Sa'ka, Special forces take specialized training in the fields of Direct action,Hostage rescue,Counter-terrorism,Unconventional warfare,Special reconnaissance,Asymmetric warfare. However, most information about Egyptian Army's units are classified.
Notable Special Forces in the Egyptian Armed Forces:

list.listitem: Sa'ka Forces(Egyptian Thunderbolt Forces)
Unit 777,counter-terrorismandSpecial operationsunit.
Unit 999,Special operationsandreconnaissanceunit.
Navy Sa'ka (Navy Thunderbolt)

article.paragraph: Special forces from officers and noncommissioned officers from Infantry, Sa'ka, Paratroopers and Navy can take theSealcourse which is considered the most advanced course in the Egyptian Armed Forces.
article.heading: Equipment

template.arg: Equipment of the modern Egyptian Army
List of aircraft of the Egyptian Air Force
List of ships of the Egyptian Navy

article.heading: Military Industry
article.paragraph: mainEgyptian Military IndustryFile:Egyptian Military Police in Alexandria.jpgthumbEgyptian-madeFahd (armored personnel carrier)Fahd APCIn addition to importing weapons, Egypt maintains a large industrial fortress as its military industry is considered the most important in theArab World. State-owned enterprises which are under control of the Armament Authority headed by a major general, are the main domestic producers of Egypt's defense systems.

Arab Organization for Industrialization, which has about 19,000 employees out of which are 1250 engineers, more than nine military factories producing both civilian and military products, is considered Egypt military's most important domestic weapons supplier.

Egypt's Main battle tank theM1 Abramsis made locally under license in addition to Egyptian-UpgradedRamses II tankRamses II,T-62#EgyptT-62andT-62#T-54/T-55 upgradesT-45E.Egyptian Military industry includesSA-7#EgyptSakr Eyemissiles, (ZU-23-2#EgyptNile 23,#EgyptSinai 23) Self-propelled air defense, RPGs.Hongdu JL-8#VariantsK-8ETrainer aircraft, in addition to aircraft overhaul and maintenance.

Locally made military vehicles include variousFahd (armored personnel carrier)FahdAPCs and IFVs,Egyptian Infantry Fighting VehicleEFIVs,Variants of the M113 armored personnel carrier#EgyptSIFV,Walid (armored personnel carrier)Walid MKII,Jeep Wrangler#TJ (19972006)Jeep Wrangler TJL,Jeep J8##ProductionJeep J8, Kader-320 armored vehicle,Mercedes-Benz G-Class#Military operatorsMercedes G-320 armored vehicle,Iveco VM 90andLand Rover Tangi#The Hotspur HussarHotspur HUSSARD.

Egypt also locally produces small arms such asBeretta M1951Helwan,Beretta 92#CopiesHelwan 920guns, Misr machine gun,AKM#Local use and local versionsMaadiassault rifles,FN Minimi,FN MAG,SG-43 Goryunov,Mk 19 grenade launcherMK19.
article.heading: Weapons of mass destruction
article.paragraph: mainEgypt and weapons of mass destructionFile:Red Cross at Uqd.jpgthumbwidthpxThe International Red Cross hospital at Uqd.Egypt, with a history of using weapons of mass destruction, remains one of only four countries not to sign theChemical Weapons Conventionand hasn't ratified theBiological Weapons Convention. Egypt's chemical weapons program is the most developed of its pursuit of developing a Weapons of Mass Destruction program though it is thought this reached its peak in the 1960s. Egypt was one of the few countries to use chemical weapons after WWI during theNorth Yemen Civil Warwhen phosgene and mustard gas was used againstMutawakkilite Kingdom of YemenRoyalist forcesin Northern Yemen. Egypt has maintained a policy of not signing the Chemical Weapons Convention until questions regarding Israel's nuclear weapons program are answered.cite webhttp://www.fas.org/nuke/guide/egypt/cw/Chemical Weapons Program – EgyptFas.org2014-02-03Egypt signed theBiological and Toxin Weapons Convention(BWC) on 10 April 1972 but has not ratified it.
Prior to signing the BWC PresidentAnwar Sadatof Egypt made the following comment to a question about Israel and should they use Biological weapons.

paragraph.italics: "The only reply to biological warfare is that we too should use biological warfare. I believe that the density of the Israeli population confined in a small area would provide the opportunity to reply with the same weapon if they should begin using it. Briefly, we have the instruments of biological warfare in the refrigerators and we will not use them unless they begin to use them."
paragraph.extension: Julian Perry Robinson, The Problem of Chemical and Biological Warfare: Volume II: CB Weapons Today(Stockholm, SIPRI, 1973), p. 241.

article.heading: Military budget
article.paragraph: File:Military expenditure by country map2.pngthumbright280pxMilitary spending of countries around the world.Arming 4 billion and $300 million budget, but not worth anything in front of the budgets of arming the major powers in the Middle East armies,

Balancing the Egyptian armed forces, a military and therefore must be kept secret. As part of what the Egyptian army's budget is linked to military activities such as buying weapons or production, and in the matter of information on this Menkhvh and published for the whole world of enemy and friend part because there is a major strategic ally, which is committed to transparency in front of his countrymen publish everything about himself and those who receive him military aid in the form ofweaponsor the production of the wars in common with them, and this is a strategic ally is the United States that the Egyptian armed forces awarded $1.3 billion annually in support and in 2014 lifted the United States budgetary to reach 1.43 billion of annual support through its program for "foreign military financing," and then published by the government as "US Government Accounting Office" or the ministries of defense, foreign affairs or what Congress and the details of his license or help in the production factories of the Egyptian army tanks and so on. And the part that the armed forces reserves the secret is in relation to the enormous Bmdjulha of the unknown is warfare activities, such as the Civil Misc of household tools, and structural and other civilian sectors
article.heading: Military exercises

template.arg:
'''Left:''' Aircraft over the pyramids during Bright Star '83
'''Right:''' Egyptian, Pakistani and American paratroopers during Military Operations in Urban Terrain training at the Mubarak Military City

article.paragraph: The Egyptian Armed forces' different branches are engaged in annually military exercises locally in addition to exercises with different armies including:

list.listitem: Operation Bright Star, one of the largest joint training exercises in the world led by theUS Armed ForcesAmericanand the Egyptian Armed Force.
Sea of Friendship Maneuvers, held inMediterranean Seathe Mediterranean Seabetween the navy forces of theEgyptian NavyEgyptandTurkish NavyTurkey.
Tabuk Maneuvers, held in Saudi Arabia with theSaudi Armed Forces.
Morgan Maneuvers, held in Saudi Arabia between the navy forces ofEgyptian NavyEgyptandSaudi NavySaudi Arabia.
Faisal Maneuvers, held in Saudi Arabia between the Air Forces ofEgyptian Air ForceEgyptandRoyal Saudi Air ForceSaudi Arabia.
Zaid Maneuvers, held in United Arab Emirates with theUnion Defence Force (UAE)Union Defence Force.
Ein Jalut Maneuvers, held in Jordan, with theJordanian Armed Forces.
Ra'd Maneuvers, held in the western command between different army branches.
Badr Maneuvers, held by the Third Army command between different army branches.
Nasr Maneuvers, held by the Second Army command between different army branches.
Sea's Victory Maneuvers, held by theEgyptian Navynavy commandbetween different army branches.

article.heading: Military uniforms
Participation in United Nations peacekeeping
article.paragraph: Image:SRSG first visit to Bukavu (10225409304).jpgthumb220pxMembers of Egyptian special forces perform during a medal parade in BukavuImage:Egyptian medical personnel at Bagram Air Base.jpgthumbwidthpxEgyptian medical personnel for their support during a tour of the Egyptian field hospital in Bagram.Image:SRSG first visit to Bukavu (10225509315).jpgthumb220pxEgyptian contingent celebrate during a medal parade in Bukavu.Because the Egyptian military capabilities and potentials, it is always choose battalions to participate externally in establishing stability and peace in the well strained in the world, within the peacekeeping forces, Egypt is one of the largest troop-contributing countries in United Nations peacekeeping missions, where he is currently involved about 2613 troops in missions UN deployed in several regions and countries in Africa, and countries that Egypt participated in international peacekeeping forces:

list.listitem: Sarajevoduring the civil war in 1990s.
Ivory Coast to help the Ivorian parties to implement the peace agreement signed between them in the January 2003, and end the civil war.
Congo during the period of the civil war during the period of 1960 to 1961 number 2 secret umbrellas sized 258.

Somalia number one pedestrian mechanical battalion-sized 240 in the period from December 1992 to May 1993 after it increased the size of the force involved in the period from May 1993 through February 1995 to 1680 people made up of the leadership of the brigade and three infantry battalions mechanic entrusted with the protection ofAden Adde International AirportMogadishu Airportand the training of police officers theSomalisSomali.

Central African from June 1998 and even March 2000 the number of infantry company consisting of 125 personnel and administrative unit and a medical unit with 294 persons as part of a mission United Nations peacekeeping.
Angola with 28 military observers at spaced intervals during the period of 1991 and even 1999.
Mozambique number 20 military observers during the period of February 1993 and even June 1995.
Liberia 15 the number of military observers during the period from December 1993 and even September 1997.
Rwanda number 10 military observers.
Comoros number three observers during the period of 1997 until 1999.
Western Sahara19 the number of military observers since September 1991 until now.
Sierra Leone the number of military observers since 9 September 1998 until now.
DRC 28 the number of military observers was strong support for the confidentiality of individual signal 110 since November 1999 until now.
Liberia the number of military observers since 8 December 2003 until now.
Burundi number 2 military observers since September 2004 until now.

DarfurSudan the number of 34 military observers and three officers Authority leaders since August 2004 as part of the security forcesAfrican UnionbDarfur, this Unlike the Post mission United Nations in Sudan estimated the number of people in 1046.

article.paragraph: In order to support peacekeeping efforts of the African continent, the Egypt the establishment of the Cairo Center for Training on Conflict Resolution and Peacekeeping in Africa and in the year 1995 to train about 200 students per year fromAfricaAfrican countriesspeaking by French and English and Portuguese in order to strengthen cooperation and interaction between the linguistic and cultural groups in Africa, the Centre collaborates closely with the mechanismAfrican Unionto prevent disputes and also with a number of preservation institutions peace, including the Pearson peacekeeping Centre.
article.heading: Non-Military affairs
article.paragraph: The Egyptian Armed Forces established the "The National Service's projects' organization" which has more than 10 sub-companies and factories specialized in public service and civil production including chemicals, Cements, plastics, housing construction, consumer goods and military-owned resorts management.

The Armed forces of Egypt helped in building several national projects such as construction of Egypt's main roads, bridges, tunnels, ports, stadiums, clubs, hospitals, international medical centers, medical units, schools, scientific centers, educational centers, cities, factories, desert land reclamation, slums developments, water desalination plants and faculties.cite newshttp://www.mod.gov.eg/Mod/Mod_EAA.aspxThe National Service's projects' organizationEgyptian Ministry of Defence

Egyptian Armed forces also has 3 football clubs playing in theEgyptian Premier League.El-Entag El-Harby SC(Military Production),Tala'ea El-Gaish SC(Army's Vanguards) andHaras El-Hodood SC(Border Guards).
